name: 1-bromo-4-ethylbenzene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.

name: 1-bromo-4-ethylbenzene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The ethyl group typically lowers the melting point compared to hydrogen due to the alkyl chain providing more entropy and disrupting crystal packing (-25 °C). A bromine atom increases the melting point due to its significant mass and polarizability compared to hydrogen (+35 °C).

name: 1-bromo-4-ethylbenzene
source: Dreisbach R. R. Physical Properties of Chemical Compounds; Vol. I; American Chemical Society; Washington; 1955.
Reason: The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The ethyl group typically lowers the melting point compared to hydrogen due to the alkyl chain providing more entropy and disrupting crystal packing, which can be estimated around -25 °C. A bromine atom increases the melting point due to its significant mass and polarizability compared to hydrogen; this effect can raise the melting point approximately by +35 °C. However, the actual value of -43.25 °C suggests that the combined effect of these functional groups leads to a much lower melting point than predicted. The discrepancy can arise because the polarizability and mass of bromine may not exert as strong an increasing effect on the melting point as initially estimated, and the alkyl chain's influence on lowering the melting point could be greater due to more effective disruption of crystal packing.
